docs.snippet: The speaker of the Israeli Parliament said today that in an effort to break a cycle of violence and revenge, he would accept an invitation to address the Palestinian legislative council despite the objections of Prime Minister Ariel Sharon.    The...
docs.lead_paragraph: The speaker of the Israeli Parliament said today that in an effort to break a cycle of violence and revenge, he would accept an invitation to address the Palestinian legislative council despite the objections of Prime Minister Ariel Sharon. The speaker, Avraham Burg, a dovish member of the Labor Party, was in Paris on a joint visit with the speaker of the Palestinian legislature, Ahmed Qurei, known as Abu Ala. Mr. Burg said the invitation from Mr. Qurei was a chance for dialogue that should be seized.
docs.abstract: Avraham Burg, speaker of Israeli Parliament, says he will accept invitation to address Palestinian legislative council, over objections of Prime Min Ariel Sharon, in bid to break cycle of violence and revenge; calls invitation from council speaker Ahmed Qurei, known as Abu Ala, chance for dialogue; they are on joint visit to Paris; Sharon holds move will hurt Israel; two Israeli women die of wounds sustained in shooting spree by Palestinian gunman in Jerusalem; thousands of angry Palestinians march in funeral, Nablus, West Bank, for three of four Hamas militants killed in Israeli raid; demand revenge (M)

headline.main: Sharon Opposes Lawmaker's Plan to Meet Palestinian Council

docs.snippet: President Andrés Pastrana warned Colombian rebels to ''make progress'' in setting up a timetable for talks about a cease-fire. ''Negotiating in the middle of the conflict has finished,'' he said, ''and we need progress quickly.'' Mr. Pastrana has...
docs.lead_paragraph: President Andrés Pastrana warned Colombian rebels to ''make progress'' in setting up a timetable for talks about a cease-fire. ''Negotiating in the middle of the conflict has finished,'' he said, ''and we need progress quickly.'' Mr. Pastrana has until Sunday to decide whether to renew the rebel hold on a huge demilitarized zone ceded to them by the government three years ago. Mr. Pastrana's words came three days after he and the rebels agreed to talk about a cease-fire, a deal that came after five days of tense negotiations aimed at patching up stalled efforts toward peace. Juan Forero (NYT)
docs.abstract: Pres Andres Pastrana of Colombia warns Colombian rebels of need for progess in quickly setting up timetable for cease-fire (S)

headline.main: World Briefing | Americas: Colombia: Pastrana Urges Steps To Peace

docs.snippet: A 12-year-old Colombian boy, whose deathbed plea to see his kidnapped father touched this war-weary nation, died of cancer today, provoking fresh outrage at rebels who snubbed the boy's wish, relatives said.    Andrés Felipe Pérez died at his ho...
docs.lead_paragraph: A 12-year-old Colombian boy, whose deathbed plea to see his kidnapped father touched this war-weary nation, died of cancer today, provoking fresh outrage at rebels who snubbed the boy's wish, relatives said. Andrés Felipe Pérez died at his home in the southern city of Buga after suffering a respiratory crisis, doctors said.
docs.abstract: Andres Felipe Perez, 12, whose deathbed plea to see his kidnapped policeman father Norberto Perez touched war-weary Colombia, dies of cancer; death spurs fresh outrage at rebels who snubbed his wish; photo (M)

headline.main: Boy Who Moved Colombia, Not Rebels, Dies

docs.snippet: A former Rwandan Catholic priest charged with involvement in the genocidal massacres of 1994 has been arrested in Cameroon and will be transferred to a United Nations tribunal in Tanzania, the Internews agency said today.     The former priest, Ho...
docs.lead_paragraph: A former Rwandan Catholic priest charged with involvement in the genocidal massacres of 1994 has been arrested in Cameroon and will be transferred to a United Nations tribunal in Tanzania, the Internews agency said today. The former priest, Hormisdas Nsengimana, 48, was a rector in Butare province in southwestern Rwanda and is accused of playing a leading role in the killing of ethnic Tutsi in the province. He was arrested on Thursday, the news agency said, and faces charges of genocide, conspiracy to commit genocide and crimes against humanity.
docs.abstract: Hormisdas Nsengimana, former Rwandan Catholic priest charged in 1994 genocidal massacres, is arrested in Cameroon and will be transferred to UN tribunal in Tanzania (S)

docs.snippet: A few weeks before ordering an escalation of the Vietnam War, President Nixon matter-of-factly raised the idea of using a nuclear bomb. His national security adviser, Henry A. Kissinger, quickly dissuaded him.    Mr. Nixon's abrupt suggestion, bur...
docs.lead_paragraph: A few weeks before ordering an escalation of the Vietnam War, President Nixon matter-of-factly raised the idea of using a nuclear bomb. His national security adviser, Henry A. Kissinger, quickly dissuaded him. Mr. Nixon's abrupt suggestion, buried in 500 hours of tapes released today at the National Archives, came after Mr. Kissinger had presented a variety of options for stepping up the war effort, among them attacking power plants and docks, in an April 25, 1972, conversation in the Executive Office Building in Washington.
docs.abstract: Tapes released at National Archives show that Pres Richard M Nixon matter-of-factly raised idea of using nuclear bomb in Vietnam War in 1972, but was quickly dissuaded by his national security adviser Henry A Kissinger; few weeks later, Nixon ordered biggest escalation of war since 1968 (S)

headline.main: Nixon Proposed Using A-Bomb In Vietnam War

docs.snippet: Colombian guerrillas and government negotiators met in a rebel enclave today to try to hammer out a timetable for agreeing on a cease-fire before a Sunday deadline as troops massed nearby.    In the latest of a series of ultimatums declared by the...
docs.lead_paragraph: Colombian guerrillas and government negotiators met in a rebel enclave today to try to hammer out a timetable for agreeing on a cease-fire before a Sunday deadline as troops massed nearby. In the latest of a series of ultimatums declared by the increasingly tough President Andrés Pastrana, the government said it would close down a big rebel safe haven unless the five days of talks produced concrete results.
docs.abstract: Colombian guerrillas and government negotiatiors meet in rebel enclave to try to hammer out timetable for agreeing on cease-fire before Jan 20 deadline as troops mass nearby; Pres Andres Pastrana, in latest of increasingly tough ultimatums, says government will close down big rebel safe haven unless five days of talks produces concrete results (M)

headline.main: Talks Begin on a Cease-Fire in Colombia

docs.snippet: The United Nations tribunal for Rwanda has set next week for the opening of the trial of a former Rwandan Army colonel who is accused of being one of the masterminds of the 1994 frenzy of killing in which bands of Hutus massacred hundreds of thous...
docs.lead_paragraph: The United Nations tribunal for Rwanda has set next week for the opening of the trial of a former Rwandan Army colonel who is accused of being one of the masterminds of the 1994 frenzy of killing in which bands of Hutus massacred hundreds of thousands of Tutsis and moderate Hutus. Col. Theoneste Bagosora is charged with genocide and will be tried with three accused accomplices. Marc Lacey (NYT)
docs.abstract: UN tribunal to open trial of former Rwandan colonel Theoneste Bagosora, accused of plotting 1994 killing frenzy in which Hutus massacred hundreds of thousands of Tutsis and moderate Hutus (S)

headline.main: World Briefing | Africa: Rwanda: Trial For Accused Genocide Plotter

docs.snippet: The governing party won an overwhelming mandate in local elections, a victory seen as an endorsement of a truce with the Tamil Tiger rebels. Prime Minister Ranil Wickremesinghe's United National Party won all but 5 of the 222 councils, including t...
docs.lead_paragraph: The governing party won an overwhelming mandate in local elections, a victory seen as an endorsement of a truce with the Tamil Tiger rebels. Prime Minister Ranil Wickremesinghe's United National Party won all but 5 of the 222 councils, including the home constituency of President Chandrika Kumaratunga, head of the opposition People's Alliance. Barry Bearak (NYT)
docs.abstract: Sri Lanka Prime Min Ranil Wickremesinghe's party wins overwhelming mandate in local elections, winning all but 5 of 222 councils; victory is seen as endorsement of truce with Tamil Tiger rebels (S)

headline.main: World Briefing | Asia: Sri Lanka: Governing Party Sweeps Elections

docs.snippet: SOMETIMES, history never happened.     Adolf Hitler was, at one time, a painter (he might have preferred to be described as an artist), and he did, of course, have a ''little mustache.'' But a passport and visa dated 1941 and released last week by...
docs.lead_paragraph: SOMETIMES, history never happened. Adolf Hitler was, at one time, a painter (he might have preferred to be described as an artist), and he did, of course, have a ''little mustache.'' But a passport and visa dated 1941 and released last week by Britain's Public Records Office also indicates that Hitler was Jewish and that he was seeking to emigrate to Palestine.
docs.abstract: Comment on forged documents produced by Special Operations Executive, British covert agency based on Baker Street in London and charged with sabotage and subversion; bogus passport for Adolf Hitler described; photo (S)

headline.main: The Nation; And Maybe Stalin Was a Kulak?

docs.snippet: A driven and indignant Slobodan Milosevic today laid blame for a decade of carnage in the Balkans on everyone but himself, waving away charges that he was responsible for war crimes in four words: ''It is all lies.''     ''The real crime,'' he add...
docs.lead_paragraph: A driven and indignant Slobodan Milosevic today laid blame for a decade of carnage in the Balkans on everyone but himself, waving away charges that he was responsible for war crimes in four words: ''It is all lies.'' ''The real crime,'' he added, ''was the killing of Yugoslavia and crucifying me here.''
docs.abstract: Defiant Slobodan Milosevic blames everyone but himself for decade of carnage in Balkans, telling war crimes tribunal that charges against him are 'all lies'; photos; ousted Serb leader, in dramatic and tense four-hour statement, seems to seize new political mission of defending himself and fellow Serbs by attacking NATO and casting himself as antiglobalist hero who fought 'terrorists'; Milosevic denies his troops killed thousands of civilians in Kosovo in 1999, blaming ethnic Albanian rebels or NATO bombs and presenting ghastly photos and videos of mangled bodies; he expresses contempt for indictments accusing him of genocide against Bosnian Muslims and other crimes in Croatia and Kosovo; first part of trial relates to Kosovo, giving Milosevic chance to focus his attack on NATO and play to Serb audience by charging tribunal indicts entire nation; he also says he condemned Bosnian Serb shelling of Sarajevo and was lied to about concentration camps there (M)

headline.main: DEFIANT, MILOSEVIC BEGINS HIS DEFENSE BY ASSAILING NATO

byline.original: By IAN FISHER and MARLISE SIMONS
